'''Ron Porterfield''' is an [[United States|American]] [[Major League Baseball]] [[athletic trainer]].<ref name="PBATS â TB Rays">{{cite web|title=PBATS â Tampa Bay Rays|url=http://pbats.com/index.php?page=trainers&team=28|publisher=PBATS|accessdate=21 September 2011}}</ref> He has been the head athletic trainer for the [[Tampa Bay Rays]] since 2006.<ref name="PBATS â TB Rays" />
== Early life ==
Porterfield is a native of [[Santa Fe, New Mexico]].<ref name="PBATS â TB Rays" /> He is a 1983 graduate of [[St. Michael's High School]] (Santa Fe)<ref name="Long journey leads">{{cite news|last=Barron|first=James|title=World Series: Long journey leads St. Michael's grad to Tampa Bay|url=http://www.santafenewmexican.com/Sports/Long-journey-leads-St--Michael-s-grad-to-the-World-Series-with-|accessdate=12 October 2011|newspaper=Santa Fe New Mexican|date=21 October 2008}}</ref> and a 1988 graduate of [[New Mexico State University]].<ref name="PBATS â TB Rays" />
== Professional baseball career ==
=== Houston Astros (1988â1996) === Porterfield began his professional baseball career as the trainer for the 1988 [[Auburn Astros]] of the Class A [[New YorkâPenn League]].<ref name="PBATS â TB Rays" /> Porterfield continued working in the [[Houston Astros]] [[minor league baseball|minor league]] system through the 1996 season.<ref name="PBATS â TB Rays" /> He was named [[Texas League]] "Athletic Trainer of the Year" in 1992.<ref name="PBATS â TB Rays" />
=== Tampa Bay Rays (1997âpresent) === In 1997, Porterfield was hired by the expansion Tampa Bay Devil Rays, now known as the Tampa Bay Rays, to be the team's Minor League Medical and Rehabilitation Coordinator, a position he held until 2002.<ref name="PBATS â TB Rays" /> Porterfield joined the Rays' Major League team as assistant athletic trainer in 2003, and was named head athletic trainer in 2006.<ref name="PBATS â TB Rays" /> As of 2011, Porterfield is one of the few remaining members of the Rays staff who have been with the organization since its inception.<ref name="Long journey leads" />
In Tampa, Porterfield has been lauded by [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] pitchers [[David Price (baseball)|David Price]] and [[James Shields (baseball)|James Shields]] for his training methods.<ref name="Youth serves Rays well">{{cite news|last=Mooney|first=Roger|title=Youth serves Rays well on the mound|url=http://www2.tbo.com/sports/rays/2011/jul/26/1/spnewso1-youth-serves-rays-well-on-the-mound-ar-246355/|accessdate=12 October 2011|newspaper=Tampa Tribune|date=26 July 2011}}</ref> Former Rays outfielder [[Rocco Baldelli]], who was unable to play for most of 2007 and 2008 due to a mysterious ailment that was originally thought to be life-threatening<ref name="Emotional Rays' trainer tells">{{cite news|last=McDonald|first=Joe|title=Emotional Rays' trainer tells of Baldelli's medical ordeal|url=http://www.projo.com/redsox/content/red_sox_rocco_baldelli0227.c78a51e.html|accessdate=12 October 2011|newspaper=Providence Journal|date=27 February 2009}}</ref> and was later diagnosed as [[channelopathy]], said his playing career, which he described as having hit "rock bottom," might never have resumed if not for Porterfield's time and dedication in pursuing a proper diagnosis and treatment.<ref name="Tampa trainer rates assist">{{cite news|title=Tampa trainer rates assist|url=http://www.boston.com/sports/baseball/redsox/articles/2009/02/28/tampa_trainer_rates_assist/|accessdate=12 October 2011|newspaper=Boston Globe|date=28 February 2009|author=Benjamin, Amalie|author2=Kilgore, Adam}}</ref> By the time Baldelli left the Rays as a free agent during the 2008â09 offseason, Porterfield had amassed a 3,000-page medical file on Baldelli, which Porterfield forwarded to Baldelli's new team, the [[Boston Red Sox]].<ref name="Emotional Rays' trainer tells" />
Porterfield shared "Major League Athletic Training Staff of the Year" honors in both 2005 and 2009.<ref name="PBATS â TB Rays" />
== Personal life == Porterfield resides in [[Parrish, Florida]], with his wife and two children.<ref name="PBATS â TB Rays" />
